column1: - It may be more accurate in younger women with dense breasts.
Three-dimensional (3D) mammography is a type of digital mammography.
Mammography is performed to screen women to detect early breast cancer when it is more likely to be cured.
- Women with a mother or sister who had breast cancer at a younger age should consider yearly mammograms.
Mammography is also used to: - Follow a woman who has had an abnormal mammogram.
- Evaluate a woman who has symptoms of a breast disease.
These symptoms may include a lump, nipple discharge, breast pain, dimpling of the skin on the breast, changes of the nipple, or other findings.

A radiology doctor (radiologist) may see the following types of findings on a mammogram: - A well-outlined, regular, clear spot (this is more likely to be a noncancerous condition, such as a cyst) - Masses or lumps - Dense areas in the breast that can be breast cancer or hide breast cancer - Calcifications, which are caused by tiny deposits of calcium in the breast tissue (most calcifications are not a sign of cancer).
